TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: ka sitsuayan ka mairaw a kadjunangan, saka załum anga pulingelingetj a gadu, manu izua namalauł a keḍikeḍi a gadu.
ka sicoayan ka mairaw a kadjonangan, saka zaljom anga polingelingetj a gado, mano izoa namalaolj a kedrikedri a gado.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time the earth dissolved, and the mountains everywhere became water. There was just one small mountain left.

S.FORM: qau matsay a mapułat azua tsautsau.
qao macay a mapoljat azoa caocao.
sa izua maḍusa a nasekelay tua ritsing nua łavilu itjua gadu, aya.
sa izoa madrosa a nasekelay toa ricing noa ljavilo itjoa gado, aya.
S.TRANSL: There were just two people left who hung onto a trichodesma tree’s branches on the mountain, they say.

S.FORM: qau makułi a załum.
qao makolji a zaljom.
qau mevałut azua nasekelay a marekaka.
qao mevaljot azoa nasekelay a marekaka.
S.TRANSL: and the siblings who had hung onto the tree survived.

S.FORM: nekanga nu sapuy; nekanga anemanema.
nekanga no sapoy; nekanga anemanema.
S.TRANSL: There was no fire; there was nothing.

S.FORM: qau tsikemen anga azua rugus nua łavilu a sinikelayan, sa patuti.
qao cikemen anga azoa rogos noa ljavilo a sinikelayan, sa patoti.
S.TRANSL: So they snapped off twigs of the trichodesma tree to which they had hung, and used them as drills.

S.FORM: qau maqati anga a sapuy.
qao maqati anga a sapoy.
qau petsungu anga; izuanga sikesa.
qao pecongo anga; izoanga sikesa.
S.TRANSL: and they could light a fire; they had the means to cook.

S.FORM: sa azua maḍusanga tiamadju; qau marepuvaław.
sa azoa madrosanga tiamadjo; qao marepovaljaw.
S.TRANSL: Those two who were left married one another.

S.FORM: manu puałak tu marka mavutsa, tu marka mapiłay, tu matjubang, aya.
mano poaljak to marka mavoca, to marka mapiljay, to matjobang, aya.
S.TRANSL: And they had children who were blind, crippled or scrofulous, they say.

S.FORM: saka nu matjubang pasa pairangen; nu mapiłay nu mavutsa pasa paqaluqaluin; nu nanguanguaq a ałak niamadju, aya tjautsikel.
saka no matjobang pasa pairangen; no mapiljay no mavoca pasa paqaloqaloin; no nangoangoaq a aljak niamadjo, aya tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: The scrofulous ones were sent off to the plains people; the crippled and blind were sent to the east Paiwans; the healthy ones they took as their own children, according to the story.

S.FORM: sa azua marekaka tiamadju; mavan nu sika maya a maqati a mavutsa matjubang mapiłay, aya.
sa azoa marekaka tiamadjo; mavan no sika maya a maqati a mavoca matjobang mapiljay, aya.
S.TRANSL: Now those two were siblings; and that’s why the children were born blind, scrofulous or crippled like that, they say.

S.FORM: sa ka tsuatsuay anga marepuvałavaław, djemałun anga tua marka nanguaq.
sa ka coacoay anga marepovaljavaljaw, djemaljon anga toa marka nangoaq.
S.TRANSL: After a long time of intermarriage they got to having healthy children;

S.FORM: maqati anga a tsautsau a inika mavutsa, a inika mapiłay, a inika matjubang, aya a tjautsikel a masi tsuay.
maqati anga a caocao a inika mavoca, a inika mapiljay, a inika matjobang, aya a tjaocikel a masi coay.
S.TRANSL: and so there were people who were not blind or crippled or scrofulous, according to the old story.
